author: Muralidhara Khajane
text:
The Karnataka government has decided to send a high-level official team to Maharashtra, seeking release of water from its reservoirs to Krishna and Bhima rivers in the State to tide over the acute shortage of drinking water in border districts.

Minister for Water Resources M.B. Patil told presspersons here on Wednesday that several villages on the Karnataka-Maharashtra border in the Krishna river basin were facing acute shortage of drinking water.

Chief Minister Siddaramaiah has already appealed to Maharashtra Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis and the high-level official team would visit Mumbai shortly to take forward the State’s appeal, he said.

He said the situation in reservoirs across the State, including Almatti, Narayanpur, Krishnaraja Sagar, Tunga and Bhadra, was also alarming with the water level dipping.

“The Deputy Commissioners of the districts concerned have been directed to instruct people to desist from making use of water stored in the reservoirs for non-drinking water needs,” he said.
title: Water release: Karnataka team to visit Maharashtra
